questions.text: A patient who is a diagnosed case of HNPCC, which of the following is the most common repair associated with it? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mismatch repair

 

Explanation:

 

Mismatch Repair (MMR) defect leads to Hereditary Non-Polyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC). This mechanism corrects errors that typically occur during DNA replication. Mutations in MMR genes result in microsatellite instability and contribute to the development of various cancers at an early age. In contrast, Homologous Repair (HR) defects are associated with other genetic disorders and cancers, including Bloom syndrome, Werner syndrome, breast cancer, and Ataxia-Telangiectasia like disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nucleotide excision repair: Incorrect for this context as it deals with the repair of bulky helix-distorting lesions caused by UV radiation and chemicals, leading to diseases like Xeroderma pigmentosum.

 

Option C. Base excision repair: Incorrect as it fixes small non-helix-distorting bases caused by spontaneous or induced changes, leading to conditions like MUTYH-associated polyposis when defective.

 

Option D. Homologous recombinant repair: Incorrect for HNPCC. It repairs double-strand breaks or interstrand cross-links in DNA, not typically involved in the pathogenesis of HNPCC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref- Harper 31st e/pg. 370

choices.text: Decreased NADH/NAD+ ratio and increased gluconeogenesis
Increased NADH/NAD+ ratio and decreased gluconeogenesis
Decreased fatty acid oxidation and increased glycolysis

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presents with severe hypoglycemia and fatty liver. Which biochemical changes best explain this presentation? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased NADH/NAD+ ratio and decreased gluconeogenesis

 

The increased NADH/NAD+ ratio caused by ethanol metabolism leads to inhibition of gluconeogenesis by reducing the availability of substrates (pyruvate and oxaloacetate). This, combined with depleted glycogen stores, results in hypoglycemia. The high NADH/NAD+ ratio also promotes fatty acid esterification over oxidation, leading to fatty liver.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Incorrect as ethanol metabolism increases (not decreases) NADH/NAD+ ratio, and inhibits (not increases) gluconeogenesis.

 

Option C: While ketogenesis may be increased in alcoholics, this alone doesn't explain the hypoglycemia. Additionally, gluconeogenesis is impaired, not normal.

 

Option D: While fatty acid oxidation is indeed decreased, glycolysis is actually inhibited (not increased) due to the high NADH/NAD+ ratio.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand how ethanol metabolism's effect on NADH/NAD+ ratio creates a cascade of metabolic derangements:

  1. Inhibition of gluconeogenesis leading to hypoglycemia
  2. Decreased fatty acid oxidation and increased esterification causing fatty liver
  3. These changes are primarily driven by the altered redox state (increased NADH/NAD+ ratio)

questions.text: Alkali disease of livestock is caused by an excess of which of the following minerals? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Selenium

 

Animals that consume grains containing 5 to 40 mg selenium/kg over a period of several weeks or months suffer from chronic selenosis, known as alkali disease. Signs include liver cirrhosis, lameness, hoof malformations, loss of hair, and emaciation.

 

 It is associated with loss of hair on the mane and tail, hoof deformities, and decreased reproductive performance1. It is caused by toxicity from eating plants or grain with protein-bound, insoluble selenium2. This disease normally occurs in cattle and sheep feeding on seleniferous plants

 

Selenium intoxication can also be acute and subacute (blind staggers type).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Manganese:

  • Deficiency: Manganese deficiency can lead to skeletal abnormalities, reproductive issues, and poor growth in livestock.
  • Excess: Excess manganese is rare and typically does not cause a condition similar to alkali disease.

 

Option C. Molybdenum:

  • Deficiency: Molybdenum deficiency can impair the function of molybdoenzymes, leading to metabolic disturbances.
  • Excess: Excess molybdenum can interfere with copper metabolism, leading to copper deficiency (known as molybdenosis) in livestock, characterized by symptoms such as diarrhea, poor growth, and anemia.

 

Option D. Iron:

  • Deficiency: Iron deficiency can lead to anemia, weakness, and poor growth in livestock.
  • Excess: Excess iron can cause toxicity, but it does not cause the specific symptoms of alkali disease. Iron toxicity is more likely to result in gastrointestinal disturbances and liver damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alkali disease in livestock is caused by chronic selenium toxicity, leading to liver cirrhosis, hoof malformations, loss of hair, and emaciation. This condition is distinct from the effects of other mineral toxicities or deficiencies.

questions.text: Deficiency of which of the following causes increased glutamine in blood? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ornithine transcarbamoylase

 

Deficiency of ornithine transcarbamoylase is an X-linked genetic disorder known as ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency (OTC deficiency). This deficiency impairs the urea cycle's function, leading to the accumulation of ammonia and causing hyperammonemia. Elevated ammonia levels can indirectly affect glutamine metabolism, potentially leading to increased glutamine in the blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arginosuccinate lyase: Deficiency of arginosuccinate lyase is associated with argininosuccinic aciduria, a disorder that results in the accumulation of argininosuccinic acid and ammonia. However, this deficiency does not directly lead to increased glutamine levels.

 

Option B. Alpha-galactosidase-A: Deficiency of alpha-galactosidase-A is associated with Fabry disease, a lysosomal storage disorder. It does not lead to increased glutamine levels in the blood.

 

Option D. Arginase: Deficiency of arginase is associated with argininemia, a rare urea cycle disorder. Arginase deficiency leads to the accumulation of arginine and ammonia in the blood. As with OTC deficiency, elevated ammonia levels can indirectly affect glutamine metabolism, potentially leading to increased glutamine in the blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency is a urea cycle disorder, which is inherited as an X-linked trait. Hyperammonemia Type II is characterized by OTC deficiency. Mothers also have hyperammonemia and an aversion to high protein diet. To reduce ammonia levels, glutamate combines with ammonia to form glutamine. Thus, elevated levels of ammonia are associated with high glutamine levels in CSF and blood.

 

Urea cycle disorders

questions.text: A 16-year-old patient happens to have pellagra-like eruptions on skin in spring season from the last 5 years with normal HIAA and high aminoaciduria. Indole levels in urine are normal. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hartnup disease

 

Hartnup disease is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by a defect in the absorption of tryptophan and other neutral amino acids in the intestine and renal tubules. This defect leads to increased excretion of amino acids in the urine, known as aminoaciduria. Tryptophan is a precursor for niacin (Vitamin B3) synthesis, and its deficiency can lead to pellagra-like symptoms, including dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, often referred to as the "3 D's" of pellagra.

 

In this case, the patient presents with pellagra-like eruptions and high aminoaciduria. The normal HIAA levels rule out a carcinoid tumor, which would show elevated levels of 5-HIAA in the urine due to increased serotonin production. The absence of dietary history indicative of niacin or tryptophan deficiency (as seen in nutritional pellagra) further supports Hartnup disease as the diagnosis. Additionally, essential fructosuria is a benign condition and does not cause skin eruptions or pellagra-like symptoms.

 

Note –

 

  • Tryptophan is an aromatic amino acid with a bulky indole ring side chain.
  • 60 mg of tryptophan converts into 1 mg of niacin
  • Best Treatment of Niacin deficiency - Niacin or nicotinamide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carcinoid tumor: Carcinoid syndrome would typically present with elevated levels of 5-HIAA in the urine due to excessive conversion of tryptophan to serotonin. The normal HIAA levels in this patient make carcinoid tumor an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Option B. Nutritional pellagra: This condition is due to a dietary deficiency of niacin (Vitamin B3) or its precursor tryptophan. However, the patient does not present with a history of dietary deficiency, and the high aminoaciduria suggests an alternative diagnosis.

 

Option D. Essential fructosuria: This condition is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme fructokinase, leading to fructose excretion in urine. However, it is asymptomatic and does not cause skin eruptions or any pellagra-like symptoms, making it an incorrect answer in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pellagra or pellagra like symptoms can result from (Differential Diagnosis):

 

  • Niacin (B3) deficiency due to a diet high in maize, which is low in tryptophan.
  • Vitamin B6 deficiency, since the enzyme kynureninase, which catalyzes a step in niacin synthesis from tryptophan, requires B6 as a cofactor. B6 deficiency also leads to increased synthesis of xanthurenic acid
  • Carcinoid syndrome: can be differentiated with elevated HIAA level with pellagra like symptoms.
  • Hartnup disease can present with pellagra-like symptoms due to defective absorption of tryptophan and other neutral amino acids, leading to high aminoaciduria and niacin deficiency.

questions.text: The three most important enzymes regulating the Citric Acid Cycle include all of the following, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aconitase

 

Explanation:

 

The three rate-limiting enzymes/steps in the TCA cycle are specifically listed as: 1) Citrate synthase, 2) α-KG DH (alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase), and 3) Isocitrate Dehydrogenase. Aconitase catalyzes the conversion of citrate to isocitrate but is not mentioned among the key regulatory enzymes of the cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Citrate synthase: This is incorrect as an answer because it is one of the three main regulatory enzymes of the TCA cycle. It is specifically identified as one of the regulatory enzymes.

 

Option B. Isocitrate dehydrogenase: This is incorrect as an answer because it is one of the three main regulatory enzymes of the TCA cycle. This enzyme is a key regulatory component.

 

Option C. Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase: This is incorrect as an answer because it is one of the three main regulatory enzymes of the TCA cycle. It is clearly identified as one of the regulatory steps.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The three major regulatory enzymes of the TCA cycle are citrate synthase, isocitrate dehydrogenase, and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, while aconitase serves as a non-regulatory enzyme in the pathway.

questions.text: Which of the following metabolic pathways occurs exclusively in mitochondria? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) TCA cycle

 

The Tricarboxylic Acid (TCA) cycle occurs exclusively in the mitochondrial matrix. It is the only pathway among these options that is completely confined to the mitochondria, serving as the final common pathway for oxidation of fuel molecules.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Beta-oxidation of fatty acids: While primarily occurring in mitochondria, beta-oxidation also takes place in peroxisomes, especially for very long-chain fatty acids. Therefore, it is not exclusive to mitochondria.

 

Option C. Glycolysis: Takes place entirely in the cytoplasm, not in mitochondria.

 

Option D. Fatty acid synthesis: Occurs exclusively in the cytoplasm, utilizing cytosolic acetyl-CoA and NADPH. The process requires citrate shuttle to transport acetyl-CoA from mitochondria to cytosol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the strict compartmentalization of metabolic pathways:

  • TCA cycle is exclusively mitochondrial
  • Some pathways are exclusively cytoplasmic (glycolysis, fatty acid synthesis)
  • Some pathways occur in multiple compartments (beta-oxidation in mitochondria and peroxisomes)
  • This compartmentalization allows for proper regulation and prevents futile cycling of metabolic pathways

questions.text: Which type of mutation results in the reversal to the wild type of phenotype when the mutant gene is suppressed? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mutation of tRNA

 

The correct answer is Mutation of tRNA. A suppressor mutation, specifically a tRNA mutation, can reverse the effect of an earlier mutation that produced a premature stop codon. In this scenario, the tRNA undergoes a mutation that allows it to recognize the stop codon (UAA in this case) as if it were a normal codon (e.g., serine's codon UCA). This suppressor tRNA can then insert an amino acid at the site of the stop codon, allowing protein synthesis to continue. This compensates for the earlier mutation that would have led to a truncated, non-functional protein, thereby restoring the wild-type phenotype.

 

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frameshift mutation of coding gene: This type of mutation typically disrupts the reading frame of the gene, leading to widespread changes in the amino acid sequence from the point of mutation onward. It usually results in a non-functional protein and does not suppress the effects of another mutation.

 

Option B. Addition of another normal gene: While adding a normal gene might help correct a phenotype by introducing a functional version of the gene, it does not qualify as a suppressor mutation. This option does not specifically address the reversal of a mutation at the molecular level in the same way as tRNA mutation does.

 

Option C. Deletion of the mutant gene: Deleting the mutant gene would remove the mutation but would not revert the phenotype to wild type by itself. It eliminates the gene's effect entirely rather than compensating for the mutation within the gene or another gene.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Suppressor mutations, particularly those in tRNA, can reverse the effects of a previous mutation by allowing protein synthesis to continue even when a premature stop codon is present, thereby restoring the normal (wild-type) phenotype.

questions.text: Identify the marked bond in Orange? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hydrogen bond

 

Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) is composed of four deoxyribonucleotides, i.e. deoxyadenylate (A), deoxyguanylate (G), deoxycytidylate (C), and thymidylate (T).

 

These units are linked by 3′ to 5′ phosphodiester bonds (covalent bonds) to form a long polypeptide chain. The nucleotide is formed by a combination of base + sugar + phosphoric acid. The 3′-hydroxyl of one sugar is linked to the 5′-hydroxyl of another sugar through a phosphate group.

 

The DNA strands are held together mainly by hydrogen bonds between the purine and pyrimidine bases. There are two hydrogen bonds between Adenine (A) and Thymine (T) while there are three hydrogen bonds between Cytidine (C) and Guanine (G). The GC bond is therefore stronger than the AT bond.

 

The spatial alignment of the helix allows only purine to pyrimidine base pairing.

 

A-T and C-G base pairs have almost the same shape. A mispairing will disturb the stable double helical structure.

 

 

Other interactions contributing to DNA stability include:

 

  • Hydrophobic effects - DNA has an arrangement wherein the non-polar, uncharged bases are present in the interior of the structure, while the negatively charged phosphates are present on the outside. As the cellular environment is aqueous and polar, the hydrophobic bases in the interior of the helix are kept away from the surrounding water and the hydrophilic heads are exposed and interact with the exterior water. This property increases the solubility of DNA in water.
  • Van der Waals forces - The nitrogenous bases stacked upon one another are spaced based on their van der Waals distance. Van der Waals distance is the distance at which two molecules are attracted to each other. If this distance reduces, the electrons of the two molecules may overlap causing repulsion. These forces are very distance dependent and are inversely proportional to the sixth power of distance (r6). Although a single van der Waals interaction has a very small effect on the overall structure of DNA, the net effect of several interactions leads to substantial stability.
  • Ionic interactions - The electrostatic (ion-ion) repulsion of the negatively charged phosphates on the outside can make DNA potentially very unstable. However, magnesium ions (Mg2+) and cationic proteins along with arginine and lysine residues interact with the negatively charged groups in the DNA and stabilize it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. lonic bond: This type of bond occurs between charged atoms (ions), typically in the form of salts and is not involved in the structure of DNA.


Option B. Covalent bond: Covalent bonds are strong bonds formed by sharing electrons between atoms. In DNA, covalent bonds (phosphodiester bonds) link the sugar-phosphate backbone but are not marked in the provided image.

option D. Phosphodiester Bond: This is a covalent bond that forms the sugar-phosphate backbone of DNA. It is not the bond marked in orange in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrogen bonds between purine and pyrimidine bases stabilize the double helix structure of DNA.

questions.text: An adolescent male patient presented with pain in the calf muscles on exercise. On biopsy, an excessive amount of glycogen was found to be present in the muscle. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Muscle glycogen phosphorylase

 

The clinical features described are suggestive of McArdle's disease (glycogen storage disease type V), which is caused by a deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase. This enzyme deficiency leads to an inability to break down glycogen into glucose in the muscle cells, resulting in exercise intolerance, muscle pain, and accumulation of glycogen in muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Muscle-debranching enzyme:

  • Deficiency: Causes Cori's disease (glycogen storage disease type III).
  • Clinical Features: Highly branched dextrin accumulates in liver and muscle, leading to fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and myopathy.
  • Note: This enzyme is involved in the debranching process of glycogenolysis, but the primary symptoms are different from those described in the question.

 

Option B. Phosphofructokinase 1:

  • Deficiency: Causes Tarui's disease (glycogen storage disease type VII).
  • Clinical Features: Exercise intolerance, muscle pain, and myoglobinuria, similar to McArdle's, but also includes hemolytic anemia due to the enzyme's role in glycolysis in red blood cells.
  • Note: This enzyme is involved in glycolysis, not directly in glycogen metabolism.

 

Option C. Glucose 6 phosphatase:

  • Deficiency: Causes Von Gierke's disease (glycogen storage disease type Ia).
  • Clinical Features: Fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, hyperuricemia, and lactic acidosis.
  • Note: This enzyme deficiency affects the liver's ability to release glucose, but not directly linked to muscle symptoms described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which Biochemical method is exploited for monoclonal antibody production by hybridoma technique?  (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Purine salvage pathway

 

Hybridoma technology → common methods used to produce monoclonal antibodies

 

In this process, antibody-producing B-lymphocytes are isolated from mice after immunizing the mice with specific antigen and are fused with immortal myeloma cell lines to form hybrid cells, called hybridoma cell lines.

 

 

  • Even the most efficient fusion method will give only 1 to 2% of fused and viable hybridoma cells.
  • Hybridoma selection involve screening of the fused cells from the unfused cells. It is done using HAT media (a selection media).
  • HAT medium contains Hypoxanthine-Aminopterin-Thymidine. The trick is that Aminopterin inhibits DHFR. So, it inhibits de-novo purine synthesis. Inhibition of DHFR also inhibits conversion of dUMP to dTMP.
  • Salvage pathway will occur, but only in B-cells, not myeloma cells. Myeloma cells are deficient in HGPRT .
  • Hypoxanthine and deoxythymidine allow cells with functional hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) genes to survive through salvage pathways.
  • Due to a limited life span, unfused B cells perish within a few days.
  • Unfused malignant neoplastic cells die as a result of the lack of HGPRT gene
  • Therefore, the remaining viable cells left in the media are the hybrid cells; these hybrid cells have the ability to grow and divide on HAT media because they have functional HGPRT gene from B lymphocytes

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycolytic pathway: This pathway is involved in the breakdown of glucose to pyruvate for energy production and is not specifically exploited in hybridoma technology for monoclonal antibody production.

 

Option B. Pentose Phosphate pathway: This pathway generates NADPH and ribose-5-phosphate for nucleotide synthesis but is not the key pathway exploited in the hybridoma technique.

 

Option C. Kreb’s cycle: This cycle is part of cellular respiration and energy production but is not directly involved in the selection process of hybridoma cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The purine salvage pathway is critical in hybridoma technology for monoclonal antibody production, enabling the selection of viable hybridoma cells in HAT medium.

questions.text: Although Apo B 48 and Apo B 100 are derived from the same gene but are finally translated into separate proteins. This is mainly due to?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) RNA editing

 

Explanation:

 

The difference between Apo B 48 and Apo B 100 is due to RNA editing. In the intestine, a specific cytidine in the mRNA for Apo B is deaminated to uridine, which changes the codon from one encoding amino acid to a stop codon. This results in the production of a shorter protein, Apo B 48. In the liver, this editing does not occur, so the full-length Apo B 100 is produced.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DNA Gene Mutation in Intestines: Incorrect. The difference between Apo B 48 and Apo B 100 is not due to a DNA gene mutation specific to the intestines. Both proteins are derived from the same gene, and the variation in their production is not the result of a DNA mutation.

 

Option B. Point Mutation in Liver: Incorrect. Similarly, the production of these two forms of apolipoprotein B is not due to a point mutation in the liver. The liver produces Apo B 100, but this is not because of a mutation in the hepatic DNA.

 

Option C. DNA Gene Splicing: Incorrect. While alternative splicing is a common mechanism in generating protein diversity, it is not the process responsible for the difference between Apo B 48 and Apo B 100.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Apo-B-48 is the major apoprotein of chylomicrons.
  • It is synthesized only in the intestinal cells.
  • Apo-B100 and apo-B48 are products of the same gene, but in the intestine, the mRNA undergoes editing and so produces the B48 protein.
  • It is named so because it is only 40% of the size of B100.

 

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 249

questions.text: Absolute contraindication for breastfeeding is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Galactosemia

 

Explanation:

 

Galactosemia is a rare genetic disorder where the body cannot properly metabolize galactose, a sugar present in breast milk and many other foods. Infants with galactosemia are unable to break down galactose and its accumulation can lead to severe complications. Therefore, breastfeeding is an absolute contraindication for infants with galactosemia, and they require a special galactose-free formula.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. HIV: This option is incorrect. While HIV can be transmitted through breast milk, the transmission risk can be significantly reduced by antiretroviral therapy (ART) and other precautions. In certain situations, such as in resource-limited settings where safe alternatives to breastfeeding are not available, the benefits of breastfeeding may outweigh the risks of HIV transmission. However, in areas where safe and affordable alternatives are accessible, avoiding breastfeeding is generally recommended for infants born to HIV-positive mothers.

 

Option C. Hepatitis B: This option is incorrect. Breastfeeding is not an absolute contraindication for infants born to mothers with hepatitis B. Transmission of hepatitis B through breast milk is considered low, and the World Health Organization (WHO) recommends that infants receive the hepatitis B vaccine and a dose of hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) within 12 hours of birth to prevent transmission. Breastfeeding can generally continue in these cases.

 

Option D. Cytomegalovirus infection: This option is incorrect. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) can be transmitted through breast milk, but the transmission risk can be reduced. In most cases, breastfeeding is not an absolute contraindication for infants with CMV infection. Precautions such as pasteurization of breast milk or using frozen breast milk from before the infection occurred can be taken to reduce the risk of transmission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The question aims to identify conditions where breastfeeding is absolutely contraindicated. Understanding absolute contraindications for breastfeeding is crucial for ensuring the safety and health of both the neonate and the mother. In certain medical conditions, breastfeeding can pose significant health risks to the infant, necessitating alternative feeding methods.

questions.text: What post-translational modification is essential for the stability of collagen, contributes to oxygen sensing in hemoglobin regulation, and affects immunoglobulin glycosylation? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hydroxylation

 

Explanation: 

 

Hydroxylation is a crucial post-translational modification that plays important roles in all three proteins:

 

  • Collagen: Requires proline and lysine hydroxylation for proper triple helix formation and stability. This process is vitamin C-dependent.
  • Hemoglobin: HIF (Hypoxia-Inducible Factor) hydroxylation regulates hemoglobin synthesis through oxygen sensing. Prolyl hydroxylases modify HIF-α subunits in an oxygen-dependent manner.
  • Immunoglobulins: Hydroxylation affects N-glycosylation patterns, which are important for immunoglobulin function and clearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Splicing: This is a post-transcriptional modification occurring at the RNA level, not a post-translational protein modification.

 

Option B. Gene editing: This involves DNA modification and is not a post-translational process.

 

Option C. Subunit aggregation: While this occurs in all three proteins, it's not a chemical modification but rather a physical assembly process.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hydroxylation is a key post-translational modification that affects the structure and function of various proteins through different mechanisms - direct stabilization in collagen, oxygen sensing for hemoglobin regulation, and glycosylation patterns in immunoglobulins.

choices.text: Conversion of pyruvate to Acetyl CoA
Conversion of pyruvate to Lactic acid

questions.text: Identify the anaplerotic reaction among the following? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conversion of pyruvate to Oxaloacetate

 

Anaplerotic reactions are “filling up” reactions or “influx” reactions or “replenishing” reactions which supply 4-carbon units to the TCA cycle.

 

The important anaplerotic reactions are:

 

  1. Pyruvate to oxaloacetate by pyruvate carboxylase enzyme. It needs ATP.
  2. Glutamate is transaminated to alpha keto glutarate; and aspartate to oxaloacetate.
  3. Pyruvate can be carboxylated to malate by NADP+ dependent malic enzyme.

 

The citric acid cycle acts as a source of precursors of biosynthetic pathways, e.g., heme is synthesized from succinyl CoA and aspartate from oxaloacetate. To counterbalance such losses, and to keep the concentrations of the 4-carbon units in the cell, anaplerotic reactions are essential. This is called anaplerotic role of TCA cycle (Greek word, ana = up; plerotikos = to fill)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conversion of pyruvate to Acetyl CoA: This is not an anaplerotic reaction; it is a part of the link between glycolysis and the TCA cycle.

 

Option C. Conversion of pyruvate to Acetaldehyde: This reaction is part of ethanol fermentation, not an anaplerotic reaction.

 

Option D. Conversion of pyruvate to Lactic acid: This is part of anaerobic glycolysis (fermentation), not an anaplerotic reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anaplerotic reactions, such as the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, are crucial for maintaining the levels of TCA cycle intermediates, enabling the cycle to function efficiently and support biosynthetic demands.

questions.text: A person presented with neurological manifestations mimicking UMN (Upper Motor Neuron) palsy and sensory neuropathy. The patient was pale and investigations revealed anemia. The probable micronutrient deficiency is? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B12

 

The neurological manifestations mimicking Upper Motor Neuron (UMN) palsy and sensory neuropathy, along with the presence of anemia, suggest a possible vitamin B12 deficiency. It can cause a type of anemia known as megaloblastic anemia, which can present with pale skin. Moreover, B12 deficiency can also lead to neurological symptoms such as UMN palsy and sensory neuropathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B9 (Folate): Folate deficiency can lead to anemia, but it is not typically associated with neurological manifestations resembling UMN palsy and sensory neuropathy.

 

Option C. Vitamin B3 (Niacin): Niacin deficiency can cause pellagra, which is characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. While it involves neurological symptoms, it doesn't typically mimic UMN palsy.

 

Option D. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine): Thiamine deficiency can cause beriberi, a condition that primarily affects the cardiovascular and nervous systems. However, it is not typically associated with symptoms mimicking UMN palsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to a variety of neurological symptoms, including UMN-like signs and sensory neuropathy, due to its essential role in nerve function. This deficiency can result from dietary inadequacy or malabsorption, leading to anemia and neurological complications. It's crucial to recognize the clinical presentation of vitamin B12 deficiency to provide appropriate treatment and prevent long-term neurological damage.

questions.text: Child presents with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be Zellweger syndrome. Which among the following accumulates in brain in this condition?(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Long chain fatty acid

 

Zellweger syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder. It occurs due to defective oxidation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA). Peroxisomal enzymes are produced; but their entry into peroxisome is denied. This leads to insufficient oxidation of VLCFA. Accumulation of VLCFA in CNS causes neurological impairment and death in childhood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose:

  • Function: Primary energy source for the brain.
  • Relevance: Accumulation is not characteristic of Zellweger syndrome but is more relevant in conditions like glycogen storage diseases or diabetes.

 

Option B. Lactic acid:

  • Function: Produced during anaerobic metabolism.
  • Relevance: Accumulation is associated with mitochondrial disorders or lactic acidosis, not Zellweger syndrome.

 

Option D. Triglycerides:

  • Function: Stored form of energy in adipose tissue.
  • Relevance: Accumulation in the brain is not characteristic of Zellweger syndrome; rather, it is associated with lipid storage diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zellweger syndrome leads to the accumulation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFAs) in the brain due to defective peroxisomal oxidation, resulting in severe neurological impairment and early death in affected children.

questions.text: This condition is treated by supplementation of which of the following? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nicotinamide

 

The condition shown in the image is pellagra, which is characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, often referred to as the "three Ds" of pellagra. Pellagra is caused by a deficiency of niacin (vitamin B3) or its precursor, tryptophan. Nicotinamide is the form of niacin that is typically used in supplementation to treat pellagra. Niacin supplementation helps replenish the body's stores of this essential nutrient and alleviates the symptoms associated with the deficiency. The hallmark sign in the image is the "casal necklace," a symmetrical, hyperpigmented rash around the neck, which is typical of pellagra.

 

Note –

 

If with this clinical scenario like Pellagra with an increase in xanthurenic acid in urine, it indicates that the niacin deficiency is likely due to a Vitamin B6 deficiency. In such cases, Vitamin B6 supplementation is recommended for the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency leads to symptoms such as night blindness and xerophthalmia, not the symptoms seen in pellagra.

 

Option C. Vitamin E: Vitamin E is an antioxidant and its deficiency is associated with neurological problems, but it is not related to the symptoms of pellagra.

 

Option D. Vitamin C: Vitamin C deficiency causes scurvy, characterized by bleeding gums and petechiae, which is unrelated to the condition seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, is treated with niacin or nicotinamide supplementation

questions.text: The correct order of steps in Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is: (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Denaturation, Annealing, Extension

 

Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is a widely used method to amplify specific DNA segments. The process involves three main steps that are repeated in cycles, resulting in the exponential amplification of the target DNA sequence.

 

Steps of PCR:

 

 

The steps of 1, 2 and 3 are repeated results in the exponential amplification of DNA segments of defined length. In each cycle, the DNA strands are doubled. Thus 20 cycles provide for 1 million times amplifications. These cycles are generally repeated by automated instrument, called Thermal cycler.

 

After the amplification procedure, DNA hybridization technique or Southern blot analysis with a suitable probe, shows the presence of the DNA in the sample tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of steps in Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is Denaturation, Annealing, and Extension. These steps are repeated in cycles to exponentially amplify the target DNA segment.

questions.text: The Warburg effect refers to:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aerobic glycolysis

 

Explanation:

 

The Warburg effect is characterized by the increased utilization of glucose via Aerobic glycolysis but the end product is Lactate and generate 2 ATP, even in the presence of adequate oxygen levels. This phenomenon is commonly observed in cancer cells. This metabolic reprogramming supports the rapid growth and proliferation of cancer cells by providing intermediates for biosynthetic pathways, despite being less efficient in terms of ATP production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anaerobic glycolysis: This occurs in the absence of oxygen, which is not the characteristic feature of the Warburg effect.

 

Option C. Sustained angiogenesis: This refers to the formation of new blood vessels, which is important in cancer progression but is not the defining feature of the Warburg effect.

 

Option D. Evasion of apoptosis: This is a hallmark of cancer cells, allowing them to avoid programmed cell death, but it is not related to the metabolic changes described by the Warburg effect.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Warburg effect is the enhanced conversion of glucose to lactate even in the presence of normal levels of oxygen, known as aerobic glycolysis, commonly observed in cancer cells.

questions.text: The following histological image is seen in the patient who is complaining of growth failure and abdominal distension.  Signs found were anemia, thrombocytopenia and bony pain. Which enzyme is deficient in this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Beta-Glucocerebroside

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a crumpled tissue paper appearance of cell which is a characteristic feature of Gaucher’s disease. It is a sphingolipidoses and the most common lysosomal storage disease and occur due to deficiency of lysosomal enzyme β-glucocerebrosidase. The substrate glucosylceramide gets accumulated in macrophages causing eccentric nucleus.

Other clinical features are: Bony pain, pathological fracture, hepatosplenomegaly but no mental retardation (as beta-glucosylceramide is not present in brain).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sphingomyelinase: Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Niemann-Pick disease, characterized by the accumulation of sphingomyelin in macrophages. Clinical features include hepatosplenomegaly, progressive neurodegeneration, and the presence of foam cells. Niemann-Pick disease often presents with mental retardation.

 

Option C. Hexosaminidase: This enzyme has two forms, A and B. Deficiency of Hexosaminidase A leads to Tay-Sachs disease, characterized by the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside, primarily affecting neurons. Clinical features include progressive neurodegeneration, a cherry-red spot on the macula, and early death. Deficiency of both Hexosaminidase A and B leads to Sandhoff disease, which presents similarly to Tay-Sachs but with additional visceral involvement.

 

Option D. G-6-phosphatase: Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Von Gierke’s disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type I), characterized by impaired glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. Clinical features include severe hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hepatomegaly, hyperlipidemia, and hyperuricemia. Patients often present with a doll-like facies, protuberant abdomen, and growth retardation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gaucher’s Disease

 

 

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 235

questions.text: What is the order of drawing blood sample in vials/vacutainers: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Blue, Red, Lavender, Grey

 

Explanation:

 

Order of Draw in Blood Collection (Vacutainer Method)

 

The standard order of draw is important to avoid cross-contamination of additives between tubes, which can affect lab results.

 

Here’s the correct order based on CLSI (Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute) guidelines:

 

  1. Blood culture bottles (if needed)
  2. Light Blue – contains sodium citrate (for coagulation tests like PT, aPTT)
  3. Red / Gold / SST – no additive or clot activator (for serum tests)
  4. Green – contains heparin (for plasma chemistry)
  5. Lavender / Pink – contains EDTA (for hematology, e.g., CBC)
  6. Grey – contains sodium fluoride + potassium oxalate (for glucose and lactate)

 

So, the correct order of drawing blood samples in vials/vacutainers is Blue, Red, Lavender, Grey.

 

1. Blue: The blue-top tube is typically used for coagulation tests that require blood to be collected in citrate anticoagulant. The citrate in the tube helps prevent blood clotting by binding calcium.

 

2. Red: The red-top tube does not contain any anticoagulant and is commonly used for collecting blood samples for various tests, including serum chemistry, blood bank, and serology. After allowing the blood to clot, it is centrifuged, and the resulting serum is used for analysis.

 

3. Lavender: The lavender-top tube contains EDTA (ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid) as an anticoagulant. It is used for collecting whole blood for complete blood count (CBC), blood typing, and other hematological tests. EDTA helps preserve the blood cell morphology.

 

4. Grey: The grey-top tube contains an anticoagulant called potassium oxalate or sodium fluoride. It is used primarily for glucose testing and helps preserve blood glucose levels by inhibiting glycolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of drawing blood samples in vials/vacutainers is Blue (coagulation tests), Red (serum tests), Lavender (hematology tests), and Grey (glucose tests) to ensure accurate test results and avoid cross-contamination.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with easy fatiguability and frequent episodes of muscle cramps during physical activity. The mother notes that the child often vomits after exercise. Muscle biopsy shows excess glycogen accumulation. What enzyme is most likely deficient? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glycogen phosphorylase

 

Glycogen phosphorylase deficiency (McArdle's disease or GSD type V) explains this clinical presentation. The enzyme deficiency prevents breakdown of muscle glycogen during exercise, leading to exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, and "second wind phenomenon." The muscle biopsy showing excess glycogen is characteristic, as the glycogen cannot be properly metabolized for energy during exercise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glycogen synthase: Deficiency leads to absence of glycogen in liver, not accumulation in muscles. Presents with fasting hypoglycemia and hunger between meals.

 

Option C. Debranching enzyme: While this causes glycogen accumulation, it primarily affects liver and heart with hepatomegaly being a prominent feature. Muscle symptoms are not as predominant.

 

Option D. Phosphofructokinase: Although this also causes exercise intolerance (GSD type VII or Tarui disease), it doesn't lead to significant glycogen accumulation as the defect is in glycolysis, not glycogen metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen phosphorylase deficiency (McArdle's disease) is characterized by exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, and exercise-induced myoglobinuria due to inability to break down muscle glycogen during exercise. The presence of excess muscle glycogen on biopsy helps differentiate it from other metabolic myopathies.

questions.text: A TPN bag consists of 100g glucose, 30g amino acids, and 40g lipids. What is the amount of calories delivered? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 880 Kcal

 

In patients who cannot (unconscious; removal of large part of gut) or should not (major trauma or surgery) use their gastrointestinal tract, total parenteral feeding has to be resorted. The solution may be infused through one of the large vessels like subclavian vein or superior vena cava, where the blood flow is sufficient to dilute the hypertonic solution. This procedure is known as total parenteral nutrition (TPN) or intravenous hyperalimentation.

 

The number of calories delivered by the given TPN (Total Parenteral Nutrition) bag is 880 Kcal.

 

The caloric values of different food components are:

• Carbohydrate (glucose) - 4KCal/g

• Proteins (amino acids) - 4.2KCal/g = ~4KCal/g

• Fat (lipids) - 9Kcal/g

 

Calculation of the number of calories:

• 100 gm of glucose = 100 × 4 KCal=400 KCal

• 30 gm of amino acids = 30 × 4 KCal= 120 KCal

• 40 gm of lipids = 40 × 9 KCal= 360 KCal

Total amount of calories delivered= 400+120+360=880 Kcal

 

Note: The caloric value of alcohol is 7KCal/g.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) is a method used to deliver nutrients directly into the bloodstream when patients cannot use their gastrointestinal tract. The caloric value of the nutrients provided in the TPN bag can be calculated based on the caloric content of carbohydrates, proteins, and fats.

 

Caloric Values:

 

  • Carbohydrates (glucose): 4 KCal/g
  • Proteins (amino acids): Approximately 4 KCal/g
  • Fats (lipids): 9 KCal/g

questions.text: Match the following disorders with their respective clinical features or lab findings: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 → A, 2 → C, 3 → B, 4 → D

 

The matching of disorders with their respective clinical features or lab findings is based on the specific enzymatic defects associated with each type of glycogen storage disease (GSD).

 

  1. Cori’s Disease (Type III GSD):
    • Correct Match: A. Branched structure in liver biopsy
    • In Cori’s disease, the deficiency of the debranching enzyme leads to the accumulation of abnormal glycogen with short outer branches, often referred to as "limit dextrin." This structural abnormality can be observed in a liver biopsy.
       
  2. McArdle’s Disease (Type V GSD):
    • Correct Match: C. Exercise intolerance
    • McArdle’s disease is caused by a deficiency in muscle phosphorylase (myophosphorylase), which is required for glycogen breakdown in muscle tissue. As a result, individuals with McArdle’s disease experience exercise intolerance due to the inability to produce adequate energy during physical activity.
       
  3. Pompe’s Disease (Type II GSD):
    • Correct Match: B. Accumulation of glycogen in lysosome
    • Pompe’s disease is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme acid maltase (alpha-glucosidase), which leads to the accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes. This condition is also classified as a lysosomal storage disease.
       
  4. Von Gierke’s Disease (Type I GSD):
    • Correct Match: D. Hypoglycemia with lactic acidosis
    • Von Gierke’s disease results from a deficiency in glucose-6-phosphatase, an enzyme critical for gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis. The lack of this enzyme leads to severe fasting hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, and hepatomegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen storage diseases (GSDs) are classified based on the specific enzyme deficiency involved, leading to distinct clinical features such as exercise intolerance in McArdle’s disease, glycogen accumulation in lysosomes in Pompe’s disease, and hypoglycemia with lactic acidosis in Von Gierke’s disease.

questions.text: The rate-limiting enzyme of HMP shunt is? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase

 

The rate-limiting enzyme of the Hexose Monophosphate (HMP) shunt, also known as the pentose phosphate pathway, is glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD). G6PD catalyzes the first step in this pathway, converting glucose-6-phosphate into 6-phosphoglucono-δ-lactone while reducing NADP+ to NADPH.

 

This step is crucial for the production of NADPH, which is necessary for reductive biosynthesis and for maintaining the reduced state of glutathione, thereby protecting cells from oxidative damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose-6-phosphatase: This enzyme is involved in gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis but not in the HMP shunt. It catalyzes the final step of these pathways, converting glucose-6-phosphate to free glucose in the endoplasmic reticulum.

 

Option C. Phosphofructokinase I (PFK1): PFK1 is the rate-limiting enzyme of glycolysis, not the HMP shunt. It catalyzes the conversion of fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate.

 

Option D. Glycogen phosphorylase: This enzyme is the rate-limiting step in glycogenolysis, where it breaks down glycogen into glucose-1-phosphate. It is not involved in the HMP shunt.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rate Limiting Enzymes

questions.text: Which of the following activate glycogen phosphorylase? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans A) Ca2+

 

  • Explanation: Calcium ions play a role in the activation of glycogen phosphorylase. When there is a need for energy, an increase in intracellular calcium levels can activate glycogen phosphorylase. Calcium ions bind to calmodulin, which, in turn, activates phosphorylase kinase. Phosphorylase kinase then phosphorylates and activates glycogen phosphorylase.
  • Relevance: Calcium-mediated activation of glycogen phosphorylase is part of the fight-or-flight response, ensuring a rapid release of glucose for energy during periods of stress or physical activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucose 6-Phosphate:

 

  • Explanation: Glucose 6-phosphate is a product of the glycolytic pathway and is an indicator of sufficient energy within the cell. High levels of glucose 6-phosphate inhibit glycogen phosphorylase. Glycogen phosphorylase is typically activated when glucose levels are low and energy demand is high.
  • Relevance: The presence of glucose 6-phosphate signals that the cell has adequate energy reserves and does not need to break down glycogen.

 

Option C. Glucose:

 

  • Explanation: Glucose itself does not directly activate glycogen phosphorylase. In fact, high levels of glucose can have an inhibitory effect on glycogen phosphorylase because it indicates that there is sufficient glucose available for energy needs, reducing the need to break down glycogen.
  • Relevance: Elevated glucose levels signal that there is no immediate need to activate glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Option D. High ATP (Adenosine Triphosphate):

 

  • Explanation: High levels of ATP can inhibit glycogen phosphorylase. ATP is a molecule that stores energy, and when ATP levels are high, it indicates that the cell has sufficient energy reserves. In this context, glycogen phosphorylase would not be activated to break down glycogen.
  • Relevance: High ATP levels signal that there is no immediate need for additional energy from glycogenolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen Phosphorylase is first and RLE of glycogenolysis. It transfers Pi, uses PLP (B6) and breaks α (1 à 4) bonds from one end until 4 glucose residues are left at branch point. End-product is Glucose 1–P (90%). It exists in two forms b and a. which is regulated by various mechanism shown as:

questions.text: Which of the following is not a true statement regarding telomerase? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Involved in DNA repair

 

Telomerase is not primarily involved in DNA repair. While telomere maintenance can influence genome stability and prevent end-to-end chromosome fusions, telomerase itself does not play a direct role in the classical DNA repair pathways such as base excision repair, nucleotide excision repair, mismatch repair, or double-strand break repair.

 

Telomerase is a specialized enzyme that adds repetitive nucleotide sequences to the ends of chromosomes (telomeres) in eukaryotic cells. Its primary function is to maintain the length and stability of chromosomes by compensating for the loss of DNA that occurs during cell division.

 

Additional Information:

 

  • Telomeres are repetitive non-coding DNA sequences at the ends of chromosomes that protect them from degradation and prevent chromosomal fusion.
  • Telomerase activity declines with age, leading to the progressive shortening of telomeres and eventual cell senescence or apoptosis.
  • In many cancer cells, telomerase activity is upregulated, allowing these cells to bypass senescence and continue dividing indefinitely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Has reverse transcriptase activity: Telomerase contains an RNA component that serves as a template for adding telomeric repeats to the chromosome ends. The enzyme uses this RNA template to synthesize DNA, acting as a reverse transcriptase.

 

Option B. Present only in Eukaryotes: Telomerase is found only in eukaryotic cells because prokaryotic chromosomes are typically circular and do not have telomeres that require maintenance.

 

Option C. Maintains the chromosome length: Telomerase extends the telomeres, preventing their shortening during DNA replication and thus maintaining chromosome length and stability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Telomerase is an enzyme with reverse transcriptase activity, present only in eukaryotes, and is crucial for maintaining chromosome length by adding telomeric repeats. It is not directly involved in DNA repair.

questions.text: Which of the following is not glucogenic?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acetyl coenzyme A

 

  • Acetyl CoA is not glucogenic. It enters the citric acid cycle (Kreb's cycle) for energy production and cannot be directly converted into glucose. It is primarily used for energy generation in the form of ATP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oxaloacetate: Oxaloacetate is a glucogenic compound. It can be converted into glucose through a series of enzymatic reactions in the gluconeogenesis pathway. This makes it a precursor for glucose synthesis.

 

Option C. Lactate: Lactate is a glucogenic compound. It can be converted into pyruvate in the Cori cycle, and pyruvate can then be used in gluconeogenesis to produce glucose.

 

Option D. Pyruvate: Pyruvate is a glucogenic compound. It serves as a central molecule in both glycolysis and gluconeogenesis, making it a key intermediate in the conversion of various substrates into glucose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acetyl CoA is not a glucogenic compound as it cannot be directly converted into glucose, unlike oxaloacetate, lactate, and pyruvate, which are glucogenic and contribute to glucose synthesis.

 

Substrates of gluconeogenesis (mostly 3C)                                                                                     

  1. Pyruvate (3C)
  2. Lactate (3C)                                                              
  3. Propionic acid (3C)
  4. Glycerol (3C)                                                       
  5. Glucogenic amino acids (18 amino acids)
  6. Both Ketogenic & Glucogenic amino acids
  7. Any TCA Intermediate (forms oxaloacetate which can enter gluconeogenesis)

questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is caused by the deficiency of? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lecithin

 

Specifically phosphatidylcholine, is a major component of pulmonary surfactant. Surfactant plays a crucial role in reducing surface tension in the alveoli of the lungs, preventing their collapse. A deficiency in lecithin can contribute to respiratory distress syndrome, especially in premature infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cephalin: Cephalin is a type of phospholipid, and while it is present in cell membranes, it is not a major component of pulmonary surfactant and is not directly associated with respiratory distress syndrome.

 

Option B. Sphingomyelin: Sphingomyelin is another type of phospholipid found in cell membranes. The deficiency to recycle this lipid due to defective lysosomal enzyme sphingomyelinase cause sphingolipidoses also known as Niemann Pick disease.

 

Option D. Cardiolipin: Cardiolipin is a phospholipid found in the inner mitochondrial membrane and bacterial membranes. The disease associated with cardiolipins are anti-phospholipid syndrome and Barth syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RDS is a common condition in premature infants due to inadequate surfactant production, particularly the deficiency of lecithin. The educational objective is to understand the etiology of RDS and its association with surfactant components, specifically lecithin. This knowledge is crucial for healthcare professionals involved in the care of neonates, as RDS can have serious respiratory consequences in premature infants and requires appropriate management and support.

choices.text: It has a higher mutation rate than nuclear DNA
It codes for more than 25% of oxidative phosphorylation proteins

questions.text: True regarding Mitochondrial DNA is? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It has a higher mutation rate than nuclear DNA

 

Mitochondrial DNA and RNA

 

  1. There is a dichotomy on the mitochondrial metabolism. Some of the mitochondrial protein synthesis is under the control of mitochondrial DNA; but important proteins of the outer membrane of the mitochondria are synthesized under the influence of nuclear DNA.
  2. The mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is circular, has about 16,500 nucleotides. The mtDNA has information for synthesis of 2 ribosomal RNAs, 22 tRNAs and 13 proteins. All of them are components of electron transport chain. It has 37 genes that encode 13 protein subunits of the respiratory chain (total of 67 i.e., about 20%). However, most of mitochondrial proteins are encoded by nuclear DNA and synthesized in the cytoplasm.
  3. Maternal inheritance: Since, the mitochondria are inherited cytoplasmically, the mtDNA is inherited from the mother. Mother transmits mtDNA through oocyte.
  4. There are hundreds of copies of mtDNA in each cell (nuclear DNA has only 2 copies).
  5. Heteroplasmy is defined as the presence of normal and mutant mtDNA in different proportions in different cells. During cell division, mtDNA replicates and they segregate to the daughter cells. If a mutation occurs in mtDNA, the daughter cells may inherit the mutant or normal mtDNA.
  6. High mutation rate: 5-10 times that of nuclear DNA
  7. Age-related accumulation of mutations in mtDNA may be responsible for age-related decrease in cellular OXPHOS function, and progression of other degenerative diseases.
  8. Defects in mitochondrial genome will lead to mitochondrial myopathies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. One set from each parent: Incorrect. mtDNA is inherited only from the mother.

 

Option C. It codes for more than 25% of oxidative phosphorylation proteins: Incorrect. mtDNA encodes about 13 protein subunits of the respiratory chain, approximately 20% of the total, not more than 25%.

 

Option D. It has 3 X 10^9 base pairs: Incorrect. mtDNA is much smaller, with about 16,500 base pairs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitochondrial DNA has a higher mutation rate than nuclear DNA, is maternally inherited, and contains 37 genes encoding essential components of the electron transport chain.

 

Ref - Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students 7th edition

questions.text: DNA packing is done by?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Histone

 

Histones are proteins responsible for DNA packaging. The DNA wraps around histones, forming a structure called a nucleosome. Histones are positively charged proteins that interact with the negatively charged DNA, allowing for efficient packaging and compaction of DNA strands. This packaging is essential for the organization of DNA within the cell nucleus and its regulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glycoprotein: Glycoproteins are not directly involved in DNA packaging. They are molecules composed of a protein and a carbohydrate moiety. While glycoproteins have various functions in the cell, they do not play a role in the compaction and organization of DNA.

 

Option C. Nucleic acid: DNA itself is a type of nucleic acid. DNA molecules are composed of nucleotides and serve as the genetic material of cells. DNA molecules do not package themselves; instead, they interact with histones and other proteins to undergo packaging and compaction.

 

Option D. Helicases: Helicases are enzymes responsible for unwinding and separating the DNA strands during processes such as DNA replication and transcription. They do not participate in DNA packaging; instead, their role is to facilitate the access of various cellular machinery to the DNA template.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nucleosomes = DNA + Histone proteins

 

Histone proteins are rich in basic AA such as lysine and arginine, so, carry a positive charge. While DNA due to PO42- groups has large negative charge. So, in nucleosomes, DNA and histones are tightly packed due to interaction between these opposite charges.

 

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 351

questions.text: A patient presented with dermatitis and loss of appetite. He also gives a frequent history of diarrhoea. On examination, alopecia also seen and patient has observed that he has delayed wound healing. This patient is most likely to have deficiency of: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zinc

 

Zinc deficiency can cause a range of symptoms, including dermatitis, alopecia, loss of appetite, impaired immune function leading to frequent infections, and poor wound healing. Zinc is crucial for skin health, immune function, and overall protein synthesis, explaining the diverse symptoms including skin issues and gastrointestinal disturbances.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin C: While Vitamin C deficiency, known as scurvy, can lead to poor wound healing and gum bleeding, it does not typically cause dermatitis or alopecia. The primary features of scurvy are related to its role in collagen synthesis, including skin bruising, bleeding gums, and joint pain.

 

Option C. Vitamin D: Deficiency in Vitamin D commonly leads to bone-related problems like rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults. It does not typically present with dermatitis, alopecia, or gastrointestinal symptoms like diarrhea.

 

Option D. Vitamin B3 (Niacin): Niacin deficiency leads to pellagra, characterized by the "three Ds": Dermatitis, Diarrhea, and Dementia. While some symptoms overlap, such as dermatitis and diarrhea, pellagra is typically associated with neurological symptoms and doesn't usually include alopecia or delayed wound healing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The symptoms described, including dermatitis, loss of appetite, diarrhea, alopecia, and delayed wound healing, are consistent with a disease known as Acrodermatitis Enteropathica due to zinc deficiency. Zinc is an essential trace element that plays a crucial role in various physiological processes, including immune function, wound healing, and maintenance of skin and hair. Symptoms of this disease are:

 

  • Simultaneous diarrhoea + dermatitis
  • Inflammation around nose, mouth, anus, cheeks, elbow etc.
  • It also occurs in some infants after weaning from breast milk as breast milk has picolinic acid (piconilic acid increases Zn absorption from intestine)           

 

 

Ref: Textbook of Medical biochemistry 3rd edition Page no. 414

questions.text: Which of the following is not an amphipathic Lipid? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Triglycerides

 

  • Triglycerides are not amphipathic lipids. They consist of three fatty acid chains esterified to a glycerol molecule. These molecules are hydrophobic and do not have a polar or hydrophilic region. Triglycerides are the primary storage form of energy in the body and are commonly found in adipose tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phosphoglycerol: Phosphoglycerol, also known as phosphoglyceride or glycerophospholipid, is an amphipathic lipid. It has a polar phosphate head group and two hydrophobic fatty acid tails. Phosphoglycerides are essential components of cell membranes, where they form the lipid bilayer.

 

Option C. Glycolipids: Glycolipids are amphipathic lipids. They have a hydrophilic carbohydrate (sugar) head group and hydrophobic lipid tails. Glycolipids are important in cell membranes, particularly in nerve cells and the myelin sheath. They play a role in cell signaling and recognition.

 

Option D. Sphingolipids: Sphingolipids are amphipathic lipids. They consist of a sphingosine backbone, a hydrophilic head group (usually containing a sugar), and one or two hydrophobic fatty acid tails. Sphingolipids are crucial components of cell membranes and are involved in various cellular processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triglycerides are not amphipathic lipids, while phosphoglycerol, glycolipids, and sphingolipids are amphipathic and play important roles in cell membrane structure and function.

 

They are formed by esterification between three Fatty acids and one glycerol molecule. As Ester bond is non-polar so, molecule of TG is a non-polar. They are also called as neutral fats.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for the negative charge in fibrinopeptide A? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aspartate and Glutamate

 

Aspartate and glutamate are both acidic amino acids that contain a carboxylic acid group in their side chains. This carboxylic acid group can ionize in solution to release a hydrogen ion, resulting in a negative charge. The negative charges on the aspartate and glutamate residues in fibrinopeptide A contribute to the overall negative charge of the peptide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Histidine and lysine are positively charged amino acids that can form ionic bonds with negatively charged molecules, but they do not contribute to the negative charge of the peptide.

 

Options A and D Valine and serine are non-polar and uncharged amino acids that do not contribute to the negative charge of the peptide.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibrinopeptide A is a peptide that is cleaved from fibrinogen during blood clotting to form fibrin. Fibrin is a key component of blood clots and is responsible for stopping bleeding from injured blood vessels. Fibrinopeptide A contains a negative charge due to the presence of aspartate and glutamate residues.

questions.text: A young child presents with angular stomatitis, cheilosis, and glossitis. Further examination reveals corneal vascularization and seborrheic dermatitis. What vitamin deficiency best explains this clinical presentation? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Riboflavin

 

The constellation of orofacial symptoms (angular stomatitis, cheilosis, glossitis) along with corneal vascularization and seborrheic dermatitis is characteristic of riboflavin (Vitamin B2) deficiency. Unlike wet beriberi, this condition primarily affects epithelial tissues and mucous membranes without cardiac involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiamine: While thiamine deficiency can cause cardiovascular manifestations (wet beriberi) or neurological symptoms (dry beriberi), it doesn't typically cause the mucocutaneous manifestations seen in this case.

 

Option C. Pyridoxine: Though pyridoxine deficiency can cause angular stomatitis and glossitis, it typically presents with peripheral neuropathy and seizures, which are absent in this case.

 

Option D. Niacin: Niacin deficiency (pellagra) presents with dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. While it can cause glossitis, it doesn't typically cause corneal vascularization or the specific pattern of facial dermatitis seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Riboflavin deficiency primarily affects rapidly regenerating tissues like mucous membranes and epithelial surfaces, leading to characteristic orofacial manifestations (cheilosis, angular stomatitis, glossitis) and ocular changes (corneal vascularization). This helps differentiate it from other B vitamin deficiencies which have distinct clinical patterns.

questions.text: A patient present with symptoms of dermatitis, diarrhea, and cognitive decline. Which micronutrient deficiency is most likely responsible? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Niacin

 

The patient's symptoms—dermatitis, diarrhea, and cognitive decline (dementia)—represent the classic triad of pellagra, which is associated with niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency. Pellagra is commonly summarized as the "3 Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. In severe untreated cases, it can lead to a fourth "D," which is death. Niacin deficiency can occur due to poor dietary intake, malabsorption disorders, or conditions that affect tryptophan metabolism, such as Hartnup disease and carcinoid syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiamine: Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency leads to beriberi, which manifests as dry beriberi (peripheral neuropathy) or wet beriberi (cardiac failure). It can also cause Wernicke's encephalopathy and Korsakoff's psychosis, particularly in alcoholics, but it does not cause dermatitis or diarrhea.

 

Option C. Pyridoxine: Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) deficiency is associated with symptoms such as peripheral neuropathy, depression, and seizures. It does not typically cause the 3D symptoms seen in pellagra unless it indirectly leads to niacin deficiency by impairing tryptophan metabolism.

 

Option D. Retinol: Retinol (vitamin A) deficiency primarily affects vision, immune function, and skin health, causing conditions like night blindness and xerophthalmia, but it does not cause diarrhea or cognitive decline.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, is primarily caused by niacin deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases have autosomal recessive inheritance? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Albinism

 

Albinism is typically inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. To have albinism, an individual must inherit two copies of the mutated gene for albinism, one from each parent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. G-6-PD deficiency: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G-6-PD) deficiency is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner, not autosomal recessive. It affects males more often than females.

 

Option C. Marfan's syndrome: Marfan's syndrome is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner, not autosomal recessive. A single copy of the mutated gene from one parent is enough to cause the condition.

 

Option D. Lesch-Nyhan syndrome: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner. It primarily affects males who inherit the mutated gene from their carrier mothers.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A person had a meal at 8 pm and records blood glucose at 7 am on the next day. What’s the source of glucose in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hepatic Glycogenolysis

 

  • Hepatic glycogenolysis involves the breakdown of glycogen stored in the liver into glucose. This process provides source of blood glucose for 12-18 hours, So By 7 am the next day, liver's glycogen stores is the main source of blood glucose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dietary Glucose: Dietary glucose from the previous evening's meal would have been absorbed and utilized or stored shortly after eating. By 7 am the next day, the influence of dietary glucose on blood glucose levels would have diminished significantly. It is unlikely to be the primary source of the elevated glucose.

 

Option B. Hepatic Gluconeogenesis: Hepatic gluconeogenesis is the process by which the liver produces glucose from non-carbohydrate precursors, such as amino acids and glycerol. During overnight fasting, the liver actively engages in gluconeogenesis to maintain blood glucose levels. It happens mainly only after 18 hours or more of fasting.

 

Option D. Muscle Glycogenolysis: Muscle glycogenolysis primarily supplies glucose for use within muscle tissue itself and is not a major contributor to blood glucose levels during fasting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The person is fasting for last 11 hours. First source of blood glucose is dietary (food) glucose that can provide glucose for upto 2 hours after meals (option a is excluded).  After that liver glycogenolysis will start and is able to maintain blood glucose for next 12-18 hours of fasting (option c is answer).

 

Hepatic gluconeogenesis will start only after liver glycogen is exhausted i.e. only after 12 hours onwards (option b is wrong answer).

 

Muscle glycogen cannot maintain blood glucose as the end-product of muscle glycogenolysis is glucose 6-phosphate due to absence of enzyme glucose 6-phosphatase in muscle (option D is wrong answer). This enzyme is only present in liver cell’s ER and is used to convert glucose 6-phosphate to free glucose.

 

Ref- Harper 31st e/pg. 176

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with fissured tongue and peripheral neuropathy. Investigations showed reduced glutathione reductase activity. Which vitamin deficiency is the likely cause of this? (AIIMS NOVEMBER 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B2

 

Natural deficiency of riboflavin in man is uncommon, because riboflavin is synthesized by the intestinal flora. Riboflavin deficiency usually accompanies other deficiency diseases such as beriberi, pellagra and Kwashiorkor. Nutritional status of riboflavin can be determined by measuring the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro.

 

Manifestations: Symptoms are confined to skin and mucous membranes.

 

  1. Glossitis (Greek, glossa = tongue)
  2. Magenta colored tongue
  3. Cheilosis (Greek, cheilos = lip)
  4. Angular stomatitis (inflammation at the corners of mouth)
  5. Circumcorneal vascularization
  6. Proliferation of the bulbar conjunctival capillaries is the earliest sign of riboflavin deficiency.
  7. Personality changes

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine): Deficiency causes beriberi, which affects the cardiovascular and nervous systems, but is detected by erythrocyte transketolase activation assay.

 

Option C. Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine): Deficiency can cause peripheral neuropathy and is detected by activation of erythrocyte transaminases.

 

Option D. Vitamin B12 (Cobalamin): Deficiency leads to megaloblastic anemia and neurological symptoms, detected by serum methyl malonate and homocysteine levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B2 (riboflavin) deficiency, indicated by reduced glutathione reductase activity, can cause symptoms such as a fissured tongue, cheilosis, and peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: Serotonin is also known as? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5-hydroxytryptamine

 

  • Serotonin is 5-hydroxytryptamine. It is produced in the brain, mast cells, platelets and gastrointestinal tract mucosa.
  • Tryptophan is first hydroxylated by tryptophan hydroxylase. The co-enzyme is tetrahydrobiopterin. The tetrahydrobiopterin is regenerated using NADPH.
  • In the next step, 5-hydroxytryptophan is decarboxylated to 5-hydroxytryptamine (5HT), (serotonin). The enzyme, decarboxylase requires pyridoxal phosphate.
  • The effect of serotonin is dependent on the amount of serotonin available at the synaptic site. Part of the serotonin released is again taken up (reuptake). Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI) are widely used in the treatment of psychiatric disorders
  • Monoamine oxidase (MAO) converts serotonin to 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (HIAA). MAO will oxidatively deaminate compounds having an amino group attached to a carbon atom. MAO inhibitors (e.g., iproniazid) will cause mood elevation.

 

Clinical correlation:

 

CARCINOID SYNDROME

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 5-hydroxytryptophan: This is a precursor to serotonin, involved in its biosynthetic pathway, but not the same as serotonin.

 

Option C. 5-carboxytryptamine: This compound does not exist in serotonin’s metabolic pathway and is unrelated to its structure or function.

 

Option D. 5-carboxytryptophan: This is also not part of the serotonin synthesis or its structure; it is a hypothetical derivative that does not have a role in serotonin’s biological actions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serotonin, also known as 5-hydroxytryptamine, is a crucial neurotransmitter synthesized from tryptophan and involved in numerous physiological processes. Its synthesis involves specific enzymatic actions that are targeted pharmacologically to manage various psychiatric

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with recurrent episodes of sudden-onset stridor and breathing difficulty, particularly during feeding. The child also has easy bruising and bleeding gums. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for these symptoms? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin C

 

Explanation: 

 

In this case, the presence of stridor during feeding suggests gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), which can trigger laryngospasm. The accompanying symptoms of easy bruising and bleeding gums are classic signs of Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy). Vitamin C deficiency can lead to weakened blood vessels and increased capillary fragility, causing easy bruising. Additionally, scurvy can cause gum inflammation and bleeding. The combination of GERD-induced laryngospasm and scurvy symptoms points to Vitamin C deficiency as the underlying cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin D: While Vitamin D deficiency can cause laryngospasm through hypocalcemia, it doesn't explain the bruising and bleeding symptoms.

 

Option B. Vitamin E: Vitamin E deficiency primarily causes neurological symptoms and muscle weakness but doesn't typically cause laryngospasm or bleeding symptoms.

 

Option C. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency mainly affects vision and epithelial integrity but doesn't cause bleeding manifestations or laryngospasm.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While laryngospasm can be caused by various factors including hypocalcemia (Vitamin D deficiency), when accompanied by easy bruising and bleeding gums, Vitamin C deficiency should be considered as the underlying cause, particularly if the laryngospasm is triggered by GERD.

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibition exhibited by A. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Competitive inhibition

 

Competitive inhibition occurs when the inhibitor resembles the substrate and competes for binding to the active site of the enzyme. In the given graph, the presence of inhibitor A results in an increase in Km (Michaelis constant), indicating decreased enzyme affinity for the substrate due to competition. However, the Vmax (maximum velocity) remains unchanged, which is characteristic of competitive inhibition. The Lineweaver-Burk plot shows that the lines intersect on the y-axis, confirming that Vmax is unaffected.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uncompetitive inhibition: This type of inhibition occurs when the inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex, leading to a decrease in both Km and Vmax. The lines in the Lineweaver-Burk plot are parallel, unlike the competitive inhibition plot seen here.

 

Option C. Mixed inhibition: In mixed inhibition, the inhibitor can bind to both the enzyme alone and the enzyme-substrate complex. This results in changes to both Km and Vmax, depending on the binding affinity. The graph shows altered Vmax with an intersection that is not on the y-axis, differing from competitive inhibition.

 

Option D. Non-competitive inhibition: Non-competitive inhibition occurs when the inhibitor binds to a site other than the active site, affecting the enzyme regardless of substrate binding. This results in decreased Vmax without altering Km, seen as lines intersecting on the x-axis in the Lineweaver-Burk plot, unlike the competitive inhibition pattern here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Competitive inhibition is identified by an increased Km and unchanged Vmax, with intersecting lines on the y-axis of the Lineweaver-Burk plot

questions.text: Match the following transport proteins with their primary ligands: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1c, 2b, 3a, 4d

 

The correct matches are:

 

  1. Ceruloplasmin - c. Copper: Primary copper transport protein in plasma, carries 90% of circulating copper
  2. Transferrin - b. Iron: Major iron transport protein in blood, crucial for iron homeostasis
  3. RBP (Retinol Binding Protein) - a. Vitamin A: Specific carrier for retinol/vitamin A
  4. Transcortin - d. Cortisol: Primary transport protein for glucocorticoids in plasma

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand specific plasma transport proteins and their primary ligands:

  • Ceruloplasmin is the major copper transport protein
