  • Transferrin specifically binds and transports iron
  • RBP is essential for vitamin A transport
  • Transcortin (CBG) is the primary cortisol carrier

questions.text: Uracil was found in genetic code. Which vitamin deficiency leads to this condition:(INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Folate

 

  • Folate deficiency is the correct answer. Folate (also known as vitamin B9) plays a crucial role in DNA synthesis and repair. When there is a deficiency in folate, it can lead to the misincorporation of Uracil into DNA, causing DNA instability and other genetic abnormalities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. B12: A deficiency in vitamin B12 is not directly associated with the presence of Uracil in the genetic code. Vitamin B12 deficiency primarily affects red blood cell production and neurological functions.

 

Option B. B6: A deficiency in vitamin B6 is also not directly related to the presence of Uracil in the genetic code. Vitamin B6 deficiency can lead to various neurological symptoms but does not cause Uracil incorporation into DNA.

 

Option D. Vit E: Vitamin E deficiency does not lead to the presence of Uracil in the genetic code. Vitamin E is primarily known for its antioxidant properties and its role in maintaining cell membranes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Genetic code is related to DNA, but DNA do not contain Uracil. In pyrimidine synthesis, UMP is the first pyrimidine nucleotide to be synthesized and other two pyrimidines thymine and Cytosine are synthesized from it. Uracil to cytosine conversion requires amino group addition provided by glutamine. Uracil is converted to thymine by enzyme thymidylate synthase by methylation where methyl group is donated by methyl-THF. So, a deficiency Folate will result in thymine deficiency and may lead to uracil appearing in the DNA in place of thymine.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 333

questions.text: Which of the following techniques is based on RNA? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RT-PCR

 

RT PCR is RNA-based technique.

 

It is the method used to amplify, isolate or identify a known sequence from a cell or tissue RNA library. Essentially normal PCR is preceded by reverse transcription (to convert the RNA to cDNA). This is widely used in expression mapping, determining when and where certain genes are expressed. Tth polymerase from Thermus thermophilus may be used. This enzyme has both DNA polymerase and reverse transcriptase activities at high temperature. This allows both cDNA synthesis from mRNA followed by PCR amplification.

In ordinary PCR, DNA is detected; that DNA could be from a living or non-living organism. But in reverse PCR, mRNA is detected; that means, it is derived from a living organism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sanger's technique - Sanger sequencing, also known as the “chain termination method”, is a method for determining the nucleotide sequence of DNA.

 

Option C. Next-generation DNA sequencing technologies also called deep sequencing, is a technology that enables parallel multiplexed analysis of DNA sequences on a massive scale.

 

Option D. Western blot is used to detect specific protein.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RT-PCR is an RNA-based technique that involves reverse transcription of RNA into cDNA followed by PCR amplification, widely used in gene expression analysis.

questions.text: RBC uses which of the following substances during fasting/starvation? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glucose

 

Under normal physiological conditions, RBCs rely on glucose as their main energy source. Glucose is metabolized through the glycolytic pathway within RBCs to produce ATP, which is essential for maintaining the structural and functional integrity of red blood cells. RBCs lack mitochondria, so they exclusively use anaerobic glycolysis to generate energy from glucose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ketones: RBCs do not utilize ketones as a significant energy source. Ketones are typically used by other tissues like the brain and muscles during prolonged fasting or starvation when glucose levels are low.

 

Option C. Amino acids: While amino acids can be used as an energy source by some tissues during fasting or starvation, RBCs primarily rely on glucose and do not extensively use amino acids for energy production.

 

Option D. Fatty acids: RBCs do not use fatty acids as their primary energy source during fasting or starvation. Fatty acid metabolism primarily occurs in tissues with mitochondria, and RBCs lack these organelles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RBCs always uses glucose whether it is fed state or fasting/starvation state because RBCs lack mitochondria. As ketone body utilization and fatty acid oxidation both take place in mitochondria so, RBCs cannot use fatty acids & ketone bodies as energy source.

 

Table: Substrates utilized for energy production

 

 

  • Fetal heart and also in case of heart failure, main fuel is Glucose.
  • Brain cannot use FA as FAs cannot cross blood brain barrier.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/p 138-139

questions.text: Dicoumarol inhibits the action of vitamin K by? (AIIMS 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Competitive inhibition

 

Vitamin K Dependent Carboxylase is microsomal enzyme. It requires oxygen, CO2, NADPH and reduced vitamin K. In this process, the vitamin passes through a cycle. This process is competitively inhibited by warfarin and dicoumarol.

 

 

Vitamin K cycle

 

Dicoumarol - Structural analog inhibits vitamin K reductase

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suicide inhibition:

  • Definition: The inhibitor binds irreversibly to the enzyme, inactivating it permanently.
  • Relevance: Dicoumarol does not irreversibly inactivate vitamin K reductase.

 

Option C. Noncompetitive inhibition:

  • Definition: The inhibitor binds to a different site on the enzyme, not the active site, altering the enzyme's activity.
  • Relevance: Dicoumarol competes at the active site, not at a different site.

 

Option D. Uncompetitive inhibition:

  • Definition: The inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex, preventing the reaction from proceeding.
  • Relevance: Dicoumarol binds to the enzyme regardless of the presence of the substrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dicoumarol inhibits the action of vitamin K by competitively inhibiting vitamin K reductase, preventing the regeneration of active vitamin K necessary for blood clotting.

questions.text: Which of the following does not happen in 5' to 3' direction?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) RNA editing

 

  • RNA editing is not a synthesis process; it involves modification of the pre-existing RNA sequence after transcription.
  • It may include: Base substitution (e.g., A-to-I, C-to-U)
  • Directionality (5′ to 3′) does not apply to these post-transcriptional modifications in the same way it applies to polymerization.
  • An example of RNA editing is apoB gene and mRNA
     

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transcription: Occurs in the 5' to 3' direction, where RNA polymerase synthesizes RNA from a DNA template.

 

Option B. DNA Replication: Occurs in the 5' to 3' direction, with DNA polymerase adding nucleotides to the growing DNA strand.

 

Option C. DNA Repair: DNA repair processes, including nucleotide excision repair and base excision repair, involve synthesis in the 5' to 3' direction during the filling in of repaired regions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RNA editing, such as the editing of the apolipoprotein B mRNA, can involve modifications that do not occur in the 5' to 3' direction, unlike transcription, DNA replication, and DNA repair.

questions.text: Replacing alanine by which amino acid, will increase UV absorbance of protein at 280nm wavelength? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tryptophan

 

Tryptophan due to presence of conjugated double bonds in phenyl group has a strong UV absorbance at 280 nm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Arginine: Arginine does not have a strong absorbance peak at 280 nm, so it would not significantly increase UV absorbance at this wavelength when substituted for alanine.

 

Option C. Guanine: Guanine is a nucleotide base found in DNA and RNA, but it is not an amino acid. It absorbs at 260 nm.

 

Option D. Lysine: Lysine, like arginine, does not have a strong absorbance peak at 280 nm and would not significantly increase UV absorbance when substituted for alanine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

UV absorption occur due to conjugated double bonds in the ring. So, to increase the UV absorbance of protein at 280nm, alanine should be replaced by any aromatic amino acids such as Phenylalanine, tyrosine and tryptophan. Out of these, tryptophan absorbs ultraviolet light about ten times more efficiently than either phenylalanine or tyrosine due to presence of two rings in its side chain compared to only one in other two amino acids.

 

All other amino acid given here do not absorb UV light due to lack of conjugated double bonds.

 

Guanine is nitrogenous base not amino acid. It absorbs at 260nm.

 

Additional information:

 

Absorbance of compounds:

 

  • Proteins - 280nm (Aromatic amino acids)
  • Nucleic acids - 260 nm (N-bases)
  • NADH/NADPH - 340 nm
  • Porphyrins - 400 nm (Soret band).

questions.text: What is the function of the proteasome? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Protein degradation

 

The primary function of the proteasome is to degrade intracellular proteins. It plays a crucial role in maintaining cellular homeostasis by breaking down unneeded or damaged proteins. Proteins are targeted for degradation by being tagged with a small protein called ubiquitin, and the proteasome then recognizes and degrades these ubiquitinated proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protein folding: The proteasome is not involved in protein folding. Protein folding is a process where newly synthesized proteins attain their three-dimensional, functional structures. It typically occurs in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and is assisted by chaperone proteins.

 

Option B. Post-translational modification: While some post-translational modifications of proteins can occur in the proteasome, its primary function is not post-translational modification. Post-translational modifications include processes like phosphorylation, glycosylation, and ubiquitination, which may occur on proteins both before and after they enter the proteasome.

 

Option D. Protein sorting: Protein sorting involves directing proteins to their correct cellular locations, such as organelles like the mitochondria or lysosomes. The proteasome's main function is not related to protein sorting but rather protein degradation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ubiquitin tagged proteins are immediately broken down inside the proteasomes of the cells. The proteasome assembly has a central cylindrical hollow core. Ubiquitin-tagged proteins are taken into this barrel, and surrounding proteolytic enzymes digest the protein into small oligopeptides of 5-6 amino acids length

 

The proteasome is a cylindrical structure in the cytosol that degrades polyubiquitinated proteins. It has a central core with proteolytic enzymes. Proteins that are tagged by ubiquitin to be degraded enter the core through regulatory rings on either side of the cylinder.    

 

It plays the major role in the degradation of proteins, and is particularly associated with disposal of misfolded proteins and regulatory enzymes that have short half-lives.

questions.text: Highest thermic effect?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Proteins

 

Proteins have the highest thermic effect among the three macronutrients. When you consume protein-rich foods, your body needs to expend more energy to break down and process the proteins. This is because proteins are composed of amino acids, and the body requires energy to convert them into usable forms. The thermic effect of proteins ranges from 20% to 30% of the total caloric intake from protein.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carbohydrates: Carbohydrates have a moderate thermic effect. The thermic effect of carbohydrates ranges from 5% to 10% of the total caloric intake from carbohydrates.

 

Option C. Fats: Fats have the lowest thermic effect among the macronutrients. The thermic effect of fats ranges from 0% to 5% of the total caloric intake from fats.

 

Option D. Fatty acids: Fatty acids are the building blocks of fats, and their thermic effect is similar to that of fats.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thermic effect of food (TEF) refers to the increase in energy expenditure that occurs during the digestion, absorption, and metabolism of nutrients in the body. This effect varies depending on the macronutrient composition of the food consumed.

questions.text: A patient has microcytic hypochromic anemia and was observed to have delayed wound healing after a minor surgery. He gives history of gum bleeding also. He is most likely to have deficiency of:(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin C

 

This patient with microcytic hypochromic anemia, delayed wound healing, and gum bleeding is most likely suffering from Vitamin C deficiency, which affects collagen synthesis and can lead to scurvy. This condition is characterized by poor wound healing, bleeding gums, and can be associated with anemia. Copper, cobalt, and selenium deficiencies present with different clinical features and types of anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Copper: Incorrect. While copper deficiency can cause anemia and neutropenia, it's less commonly associated with delayed wound healing and gum bleeding. Copper plays a role in iron metabolism and antioxidant defense, but the clinical picture described is more characteristic of Vitamin C deficiency.

 

Option C. Cobalt: Incorrect. Cobalt is a component of vitamin B12 (cobalamin) and its deficiency leads to macrocytic, not microcytic, anemia. Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause neurological symptoms and is not typically associated with delayed wound healing or gum bleeding.

 

Option D. Selenium: Incorrect. Selenium deficiency can cause muscle weakness and cardiomyopathy (Keshan disease) but is not typically associated with anemia, delayed wound healing, or gum bleeding. Selenium's primary role is as an antioxidant and in thyroid hormone metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is crucial for collagen synthesis, a vital component of skin and vascular tissues. Deficiency leads to scurvy, which manifests with symptoms like gum bleeding, poor wound healing, and anemia. The anemia is typically normocytic but can be microcytic due to associated blood loss and iron deficiency.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 548

questions.text: Which among the following serves as cofactor for Glycogen phosphorylase? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pyridoxal Phosphate

 

Glycogen phosphorylase removes glucose as glucose- 1-phosphate from glycogen (phosphorolysis). It contains pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) as a prosthetic group. The alpha-1, 4 linkages in the glycogen are cleaved.

 

PLP also acts as the coenzyme for many enzymes involved in

 

  • Amino acid metabolism, especially transamination and decarboxylation
  • Heme synthesis
  • Production of niacin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine: Thiamine is a cofactor for enzymes involved in carbohydrate metabolism, such as pyruvate dehydrogenase and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, but it is not a cofactor for glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Option B. Niacin: Niacin is a precursor for NAD and NADP, which are important cofactors in redox reactions, but it does not serve as a cofactor for glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Option D. Biotin: Biotin is a cofactor for carboxylation reactions, such as those catalyzed by pyruvate carboxylase, acetyl-CoA carboxylase, and propionyl-CoA carboxylase, but it is not involved with glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) is the cofactor for glycogen phosphorylase and is also involved in amino acid metabolism, heme synthesis, and niacin production.

questions.text: Which of the following has highest glycemic index: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glucose

 

Explanation:

 

Glucose is often used as the standard reference for measuring the glycemic index, with a value set at 100. It is absorbed rapidly into the bloodstream, causing a quick and significant increase in blood sugar levels. Thus, it has the highest glycemic index among the options listed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fructose: Fructose has a lower glycemic index compared to glucose. This is because fructose is metabolized differently, primarily in the liver, and leads to a slower and lower rise in blood glucose levels compared to glucose.

 

Option C. Sucrose: Sucrose, or table sugar, is a disaccharide composed of glucose and fructose. Its glycemic index is lower than that of pure glucose because the presence of fructose moderates the overall blood sugar response.

 

Option D. Sugar Alcohols: Sugar alcohols, such as xylitol, sorbitol, and mannitol, generally have lower glycemic indices than glucose. They are absorbed more slowly and incompletely in the intestine, leading to a lesser impact on blood sugar levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycemic index (GI)- This is the increase in blood glucose after the test dose of a carbohydrate compared with that of an equivalent amount of glucose. GI is a value assigned to foods based on how slowly or how quickly those foods cause an increase in blood glucose levels.

 

  • GI measures sugar in the blood (only glucose). It does not measure fructose or glucose - fructose blends.
  • The highest glycemic index is for glucose & galactose (Also, maltose, trehalose & isomaltose get converted to glucose, so they also have high GI). Also, lactose is broken down to glucose and galactose, so has high GI. This is because glucose and galactose are absorbed from intestine via SGLT-1, which is active transport and absorbs all of glucose & galactose, even against the concentration gradient.
  • Fructose and sugar alcohols have less glycemic index because they are not absorbed completely (because glucose transporter is GLUT-5, which absorbs fructose only down the concentration gradient).
  • HFCS (High Fructose Corn Syrup)- 58% glucose, Sucrose (50% glucose) gets split into glucose, so have high GI (HFCS & Sucrose has fructose as the other component).

 

 

  • GI of Glucose = 100 % or 1
  • GI of Fructose = 25 %
  • GI of Sucrose = 65 %

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 528

questions.text: A patient was presented to OPD with features of collagen vascular disorder. Which of the following deficits is most likely to be associated with defective collagen formation? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both A & B

 

Explanation:

 

Deficiencies in both ascorbic acid and the minerals copper and iron collectively contribute to defective collagen formation. Ascorbic acid deficiency impairs the hydroxylation of collagen, while copper and iron deficiencies affect collagen cross-linking and stability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ascorbic Acid:  Ascorbic acid (Vitamin C) is crucial for collagen synthesis. It acts as a cofactor for prolyl and lysyl hydroxylase, enzymes necessary for the hydroxylation of proline and lysine in collagen. Deficiency of Vitamin C leads to scurvy, characterized by weakened collagen and symptoms like bleeding gums and poor wound healing.

 

Option B. Copper and Iron:  Copper is a cofactor for lysyl oxidase, an enzyme involved in the cross-linking of collagen fibers, essential for the strength and integrity of collagen. Iron is also involved in the hydroxylation of proline and lysine in collagen synthesis. Deficiencies in these minerals can impair collagen formation and structure.

 

Option D. Zinc & Magnesium: While zinc and magnesium are important for overall health and participate in numerous enzymatic reactions, they are not primarily associated with collagen synthesis or cross-linking in the same direct manner as ascorbic acid, copper, and iron.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post translational modification of collagen on proline and lysine residue is required for its proper hydrogen bond formation and crosslinking which provide strength to collagen fibers. These reactions require vitamin C, copper and iron as cofactors for the enzyme involved in these processes.

 

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 548

questions.text: Which of the following tissues are dependent on insulin for glucose uptake? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Muscle and adipose tissues

 

Explanation:

 

GLUT-4 glucose transporter is insulin dependent and is the only GLUT present in muscle and adipose tissues. So, muscles and adipose tissues are totally dependent on Insulin for glucose uptake.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Liver: The liver uses GLUT-2 transporters for glucose uptake, which are not insulin-dependent. GLUT-2 allows the liver to take up glucose and store it as glycogen or use it for energy production, independent of insulin.

 

Option B. Pancreas: The pancreas also uses GLUT-2 transporters for glucose uptake, which are not insulin-dependent. In the pancreas, GLUT-2 plays a role in sensing blood glucose levels and regulating insulin secretion.

 

Option D. Placenta: The placenta uses GLUT-1 and GLUT-3 transporters for glucose uptake, which are not insulin-dependent. These transporters facilitate the basal uptake of glucose to support the energy needs of the placenta and fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In MSUD (Maple Syrup Urine disorder) which of the following is not restricted:(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methionine

 

  • Methionine is not restricted in MSUD. MSUD is characterized by the inability to break down three specific branched-chain amino acids: Leucine, Isoleucine, and Valine. Methionine is not one of the amino acids that are restricted in the diet of individuals with MSUD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Valine: Valine is one of the amino acids restricted in MSUD. People with MSUD need to limit their intake of Valine as their bodies cannot properly metabolize it.

 

Option C. Leucine: Leucine is another amino acid that is restricted in MSUD. It is one of the three branched-chain amino acids that individuals with MSUD need to limit in their diet.

 

Option D. Isoleucine: Isoleucine is also restricted in MSUD. Like Valine and Leucine, Isoleucine is a branched-chain amino acid that individuals with MSUD need to restrict to manage the condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) occurs due to the inherited deficiency of branched Chain Keto-acid Decarboxylase resulting in defect in oxidative decarboxylation and catabolism of branched chain amino acids Valine, Isoleucine and leucine. As a result, these amino acids accumulate and are excreted in urine. So, for the treatment, these BCAA should be restricted in diet.

 

Methionine is a sulphur containing amino acid and do not require this enzyme for its metabolism. So, its restriction is not required in MSUD.  

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 290

questions.text: Positive charge in thick ascending loop of Henle is maintained by recirculation of which cation: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) K+

 

In the thick ascending loop of Henle, the maintenance of positive charge is primarily achieved through the recirculation of potassium ions (K+).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. H+ (Hydrogen ions): Hydrogen ions play a role in regulating the pH of urine but are not primarily responsible for maintaining positive charge in the thick ascending loop of Henle.

 

Option B. Na+ (Sodium ions): Sodium ions are actively reabsorbed in the thick ascending loop of Henle but are not the primary cation responsible for maintaining positive charge in this segment.

 

Option C. NH4+ (Ammonium ions): Ammonium ions are involved in acid-base regulation in the kidneys but are not the primary cation responsible for maintaining positive charge in the thick ascending loop of Henle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thick ascending loop of Henle (TAL) is impermeable to water but there is active reabsorption of Na, Cl and K. The cotransporter in membrane of TAL is responsible for reabsorption of 1/3 of both Na and Cl in the body. On the basolateral side there is Na/K ATPase pump which throws sodium out and K in. This K+ is transported back into lumen through Renal outer medullary K+ channel (ROMK) channel for it to be recirculated.

 

 

Ref- https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4220766/

questions.text: Glycogen phosphorylase is activated by? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calcium

 

  • Glycogen phosphorylase is primarily activated indirectly by calcium ions. An increase in intracellular calcium levels triggers the activation of phosphorylase kinase, which, in turn, activates glycogen phosphorylase. Calcium acts as a secondary messenger to stimulate this cascade of enzymatic reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucose 6 Phosphate: Glucose 6-phosphate, a product of glycogenolysis (glycogen breakdown), actually inhibits glycogen phosphorylase. It is part of a negative feedback mechanism to prevent excessive glycogen breakdown when glucose levels are sufficient.

 

Option C. Insulin: Insulin does not directly activate glycogen phosphorylase. Instead, insulin plays a role in promoting glycogen synthesis by activating glycogen synthase and inhibiting glycogen phosphorylase.

 

 

Option D. Glucose: Glucose itself does not directly activate glycogen phosphorylase. In fact, high levels of glucose signal that glucose is available for energy production, leading to the inhibition of glycogenolysis and glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen phosphorylase is activated indirectly through the calcium signaling pathway, which initiates a series of enzymatic reactions ultimately leading to the activation of glycogen phosphorylase. This mechanism allows the regulation of glycogen breakdown in response to cellular energy needs.
